body:
Hey Guys,

We are Legacy eSports and we are here to answer your questions about OPL, eSports in general and especially about our Grand Final appearance this Saturday at Luna Park!

We have been the international wildcard representative in 2014, and this split we went 10-4, an improvement on the previous split. We recently defeated Dire Wolves 3-1 in the Semi-Final and we are excited to continue our wins to get ourselves tickets to Turkey!

This game at Luna Park has a lot of assumptions and history, but we see this as an opportunity to establish OCE on the world stage, as the best teams sharpen each other, to help them bring their best against the rest of the world.

Legacy eSports is:

Top: An 'Minkywhale' Trinh - @MinkywhaleLoL
Jungle: Tim 'Carbon' Wendel - @OCECarbon
Mid: Aaron 'ChuChuZ' Bland - @ChuChuZs
AD Carry: James 'WallyThacka' Shute - @Tallywhacka
Support: Curtis 'flyingJoo' Schembri - @flyingjooo

Subs:
Brandon 'Claire' Nguyen
Elliot 'Impaired' Capell
Zachary 'Pacman' Bayne

Coach: Aaron 'Gallex' Asher / Nathan 'Maxxy' Maxwell

We will be around to answer questions for most of the evening, so keep 'em coming!

replies.body: @minkywhale thoughts on TAHM KUNCH? ;)

Tahm is super strong in lane phase but falls off in the mid-late game. Quas refunded the champ 3 times on his main account. Also Challenger series was played yesterday and tahm wasnt at all considered.

He has obvious and exploitable flaws, however i still think swip3rr will prioritize it.

Hey I get to go first!

To any player really who wants to answer, but what mental disciplines do you try and commit to, as opposed to working on your physical skills or game knowledge?

How do you control your rage? Frustration? Disappointment? Over confidence?

How much of the game is mental at the OPL level?

Hey, I'm the Mid laner of Legacy and that's a fantastic question for my jungler haha. Mental fitness is paramount in nearly every sport and especially within League of Legends. It's only been a year and a bit since Oceanic eSports has really grown so teams are constantly facing new internal issues which really shapes a team's perseverance and longevity. About 2 years ago players were constantly jumping around and no one really stayed together after a month leaving 1 or 2 excelling teams. Anyway today's OPL standard mentality within players has really improved and its something that every new player should focus on aside of their game knowledge and in game mechanical skill. Not to say that we don't get frustrated or disappointed from a tough loss in solo queue but some of us do have hobbies specifically for this issue. Such as going to the gym, running, getting a casual job and simply socialising to friends outside of the game. 

Hope my answer was informative,
- ChuChuZ
Where do you see Legacy as an organisation leading? Do you see the organisation spreading not only to other games but perhaps also to other regions? Alas, my real question Drake or Meek.

Drake

We've been careful not to overextend ourselves as an org. I'm very big on working within my means and as such haven't really seen the need to expand as aggressively as some of the other organisations within OCE. That said in the future this is something I would like to see happen and we are working toward that currently. As far as other regions go I think that would be in very long term and I can't say I've put much thought into it.

I have 2 friends heading up to Sydney for the OPL so good luck!

Though I do have some questions

1) who is squire pug lol?
and 2) How do you keep yourselves out of the "I can't do it" mindset. 

I get it too much

Squire Pug is me, the behind the scenes business manager. Think of me like the Grand Vizier, royal counselor or other semi-evil dude who pulls the strings from behind the scenes!

But in all seriousness, I am semi-old dude, father of 3, who runs a few businesses and the Legacy guys have allowed me the privilege to run interference for most of the non-gaming side of things.

What is the difference between say a gold and a diamond player  and why can a diamond beat them so easily what are some little things that a good player does to win lane or earn free kills.{{champion:83}}

Diamond players win because they understand the game better than gold players as well as generally having better mechanics. Mechanics without at least a little bit of game knowledge won't get you super far and the difference between gold and diamond (at least low diamond) isn't always that big. A little thing you could do to win lane is understanding how creep waves work when you trade. If you're fighting in the middle of their minions you are probably going to lose and when you damage your opponent you draw aggro on yourself. Being able to bait your opponent into fighting in your creep wave can be huge.

Is there a certain aspect of the game that you feel you do better than Chiefs? GL btw

Hey Dranger,  the main aspect that I believe has always given as advantage over them has been that we are a LAN team. We have always performed sub-par online and continue to struggle with some of my team mates internets whilst playing OPL but when we play next to each other we are much stronger. Besides the external elements of the game I also think we have a good understanding of the Chiefs both individually and as a team. 

Thanks for the question.
Which of you would win in a real life fight?

1) I'm a lover of diana! i think shes really strong top and even more fun to play. however my team does not agree, so she doesnt see much game time in OPL.

2) Coms are great, everyone has a role in shot calling, we feed information to each other and our captain makes a decision based on what we give him. Example:
Minky "top TP is down and he is basing"
Chuchuz "our team comp is stronger for drag" 
Carbon "Ok lets make a dragon play, bot lane shove out and come, top lane be rdy to TP"

3) I recommend watching twitch streams and asking them for tips/advice, especially pro players. Also get into the habit of being nice in game, and adding a few ppl who u mesh well with. A nice chuck of my friends are from internet interactions.

Imagine you are the CEO of Riot Games and you are blackmailed to do the following
- Do a visual rework on any champion
- Do a gameplay rework on any champion
- Remove any three champions from the game

How would you react to the above situations?

I would tell reddit and ask them what i should do.

Sit tight and watch the world burn

Hey Legacy
First thanks for the post. Love casting you guys and how much energy you bring into the room especially on LAN.
What has been your favourite LAN (Apart from WINTER) so far and why?!

Goodluck this weekend and cant wait to see the final.

Hey Spawn!
My favourite LAN was the Oceanic regional at Goldcoast. 
It was the first OCE major event and riot forked out heaps to keep the players happy, very surreal. 
Breakfast/lunch/dinner where all covered the hotel was amazing, huge rooms with double beds and beachfront views.
Riot also hosted an after party and shouted everyone drinks which was great. 
And all the pro players had one massive hotel party.

Definitely one of my most memorable LAN events
you can improve by bringing urf back.
Any of you finding it hard to go up against your old team mate ?

This answer will be subjective but for me it really is. You never really expect your team mates to leave you, especially since we were all very close to each other and really considered ourselves more of friends than team mates. Furthermore, our previous coach (Ottoke) who had really built Legacy as a team has also been assisting the Chiefs in the lead up to the finals which additionally has given me more of a personal motivation to win this series. Nonetheless, they are great people and I've respected their decision. 

Tough question Tensho, hope I gave you a bit of insight.

I guess this is at carbon the lan king,

What kind of messages do you give the team when everyones in doubt and the game is startign to look dull?

Depends on the situation. If it looks too dire sometimes I will start prepping the boys for the next game. Being able to turn around performances is super important in series. Up until that point though I am definitely telling everyone we can still win and trying to come up with a plan to do so. People are much more motivated when they think you know what you're doing so having a plan is something I always try to do.
